case_title: Alcayde Joel v. Federal Republic of Nigeria
summary: The case involves a foreign national charged with conspiracy and illegal dealing in petroleum products without proper authorization. The appellant was charged for dealing in 1,733.087 metric tons of petroleum products without lawful authority and storing 1,500 metric tons of automated Gas Oil and 3,0135 metric tons of Low Pour Fuel Oil in the vessel MT Anuket Emerald. The appellant challenged the Federal High Court's jurisdiction and the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission's (EFCC) authority to prosecute without the Attorney General's prior consent. The key issues centered around whether the Attorney General's consent was required to prosecute a foreigner, the court's jurisdiction over offenses in Nigeria's territorial waters, and the extent of Nigerian courts' jurisdiction over offenses committed outside Nigeria. The Court of Appeal affirmed the lower court's ruling, holding that the EFCC had constitutional authority to prosecute under Section 174 of the 1999 Constitution without requiring the Attorney General's prior consent.
outcome: The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal and affirmed the ruling of the Federal High Court, finding that the EFCC had proper authority to prosecute and the lower court had jurisdiction.
ratios: The EFCC shares prosecutorial power as 'any other authority' with the Attorney-General of the Federation under Section 174 of the 1999 Constitution
Section 174 of the 1999 Constitution overrides Section 3(1) and (a) of the Territorial Waters Act

The EFCC does not require the consent or fiat or certificate of the Attorney-General of the Federation to institute charges related to economic and financial crimes as defined in Section 46 of the EFCC Act

precedents.name: Amadi v. F.R.N. (2008) 18 NWLR (Pt. 1119) 259
precedents.context: In short, in Amadi v. F.R.N. (2008) 18 NWLR (Pt. 1119) 259 at 276-277 the Apex Court held inter alia that 'Mr. Hassan being a staff of the E.F.C.C. who signed the charge was competent to do so. Any staff of E.F.C.C. can exercise the power delegated to the EFCC in Exhibit 'A'.

precedents.name: Pharma Deko Plc v. N.S.I.T.F.M.B. (2011) 5 NWLR (Pt. 1241) 431
precedents.context: See also Pharma Deko Plc v. N.S.I.T.F.M.B. (supra) cited by the respondent.

precedents.name: Jolly Nyame v. F.R.N. (2010) 7 NWLR (Pt. 1193) 344
precedents.context: Having regard to the fact that the E.F.C.C. Act donates prosecutorial power to the E.F.C.C. in Sections 13(2) and 42 of the said Act which was judicially accepted by the Supreme Court, particularly in Jolly Nyame v. F.R.N. (supra) cited by the respondent

precedents.name: Akingbola v. F.R.N. (2012) 9 NWLR (Pt. 1306) 511
precedents.context: and the other series of cases decided by the Court of Appeal of Nigeria, particularly Akingbola (supra) and Adigwe (supra) cited by the respondent
